contextId.information: Hannah speaks as if a petition were a physical object that one person could give another, and she speaks of a petition as if it were the answer to the petition that she made. The abstract noun "petition" can be translated as a verb phrase. AT: "has agreed to do what I solemnly requested that he do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: has given me my petition which I asked of him

contextId.information: A horn is a symbol of strength. AT: "I am now strong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: My horn is exalted

contextId.information: Eli was not Samuel's true father. Eli speaks as if he were Samuel's father to show Samuel that he is not angry but that Samuel needs to listen to him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my son

contextId.information: Eli was not Samuel's true father. Eli speaks as if he were Samuel's father to show Samuel that he is not angry but that Samuel needs to answer him. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:01:05|1:6]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my son

contextId.information: Eli was not the other man's true father. Eli speaks as if he were the man's father to show the man that he is not angry but that the man needs to answer him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my son

contextId.information: The writer speaks of money that people would give Samuel's sons as if it were a person or animal running away from Samuel's sons, and he speaks of Samuel's sons as if they were physically chasing that person or animal. AT: "they worked hard to gain money by being dishonest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: chased after dishonest gain

contextId.information: The Philistines hating the Israelites is spoken of as if the Israelites had become a bad smell that offended the Philistines. AT: "the Philistines hated the Israelites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Israel had become a rotten smell to the Philistines

contextId.information: The Philistines implied that the Hebrews had been hiding in holes in the ground like animals. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: coming out of the holes where they have hidden themselves

contextId.information: Here the obligation to obey an oath is spoken of as if the people were bound with ropes. AT: "commanded that the people obey his oath" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: bound the people with an oath

contextId.information: Here anger is spoken of as if it were a fire that could be kindled.  AT: "Eliab became angry with David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Eliab's anger was kindled against David

contextId.information: Here a dog represents a small animal that a person can easily kill. The word "sticks" refers to David's staff and shows Goliath's opinion that it is not a good weapon. Goliath uses this question to accuse David of insulting him. AT: "You insult me by coming at me with mere sticks as if I were just a dog!"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Am I a dog, that you come to me with sticks?

contextId.information: Goliath speaks of killing David and leaving his body on the ground for the animals to eat it as if he were to give David's body to the animals. AT: "I will kill you, and the birds of the heavens and the beasts of the field will eat your body" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will give your flesh to the birds of the heavens and to the beasts of the field

contextId.information: David speaks of leading the Israelites in killing the Philistines and leaving their bodies on the ground for the animals to eat them as if he were to give their bodies to the animals. AT: "We Israelites will kill the Philistine army, and the birds of the heavens and the wild beasts of the earth will eat them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will give the dead bodies ... to the birds ... and to the wild beasts of the earth

contextId.information: Very close friendship is spoken of as if it were binding together the souls of two people. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Jonathan felt a strong affection towards David" or "Jonathan committed himself to David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: the soul of Jonathan was bound to the soul of David

contextId.information: The phrases "in the eyes of" and "in the sight of" mean the same thing. The opinion of the people is spoken of as something that they view as either good or bad. AT: "This was pleasing in the opinions of all the people and of Saul's servants" or "This pleased all the people and Saul's servants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: This was pleasing in the eyes of all the people and also in the sight of Saul's servants

contextId.information: Harming someone is spoken of as if it were placing one's hand on that person. Here, Saul is referring to killing David. AT: "I will not be the one to kill him; I will let the Philistines kill him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
contextId.quote: Let not my hand be on him, but let the hand of the Philistines be on him

contextId.information: Here the eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. AT: "I have pleased you" or "you consider me favorably" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I have found favor in your eyes

contextId.information: Here the eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:20:03|20:3]]. AT: "I have pleased you" or "you consider me favorably" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: if I have found favor in your eyes

contextId.information: The word "flea" is a metaphor for a person whom others do not consider important. AT: "You are pursuing a person who is as unimportant as a flea" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
contextId.quote: After a flea

contextId.information: David's men were like a wall around a city that protects the people in the city from their enemies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: They were a wall

contextId.information: Abigail speaks of David's life as if it were a long and thin object that a person could put with other long and thin objects and then tie together into a bundle with a rope. This can be translated in active form. AT: "Yahweh your God will bind the life of my master in the bundle of the living" or "Yahweh your God will keep you alive with those who are alive" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: the life of my master will be bound in the bundle of the living by Yahweh your God

contextId.information: Abigail speaks of David's enemies' lives as if they were small objects like a stone that could be put in a sling and shot a long distance. AT: "he will kill your enemies as easily as a man slings a stone a long distance" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: he will sling away the lives of your enemies, as from the pocket of a sling

contextId.information: Saul was not David's true father. Saul speaks as if he were David's father to show David that he wants David to trust and respect him as David would trust and respect his own father. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my son

contextId.information: David uses the word "flea" as a metaphor for a person, himself, who cannot do any great harm. AT: "this single flea" or "me, and I cannot harm you any more than one flea can" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the one flea

contextId.information: Saul was not David's true father. Saul speaks as if he were David's father to show David that he wants David to trust and respect him as David would trust and respect his own father. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my son

contextId.information: Here the eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:26:21|26:21]]. AT: "I have considered your life to be very valuable" or "I showed you today that I really do respect you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: your life was precious in my eyes today

contextId.information: Saul was not David's true father. Saul speaks as if he were David's father to show David that he wants David to trust and respect him as David would trust and respect his own father. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: my son

contextId.information: Here the eyes represent seeing, and seeing represents thoughts or judgment. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:20:03|20:3]]. AT: "If I have pleased you" or "If you consider me favorably" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: If I have found favor in your eyes

contextId.information: Samuel speaks as if the kingdom were a physical object that could be held in the hand and grabbed out by another person. AT: "made you so you are no longer king" or "made another person king in your place" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: torn the kingdom out of your hand

contextId.information: Samuel speaks as if the people of Israel were a small object that Yahweh would give to the Philistines, whom he speaks of as if they were one person. AT: "Yahweh will allow the Philistines to do whatever they want to do to you and the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh will hand over Israel and you into the hand of the Philistines

contextId.information: Samuel speaks as if the army of Israel were a small object that Yahweh would give to the Philistines, whom he speaks of as if they were one person. AT: "Yahweh will allow the Philistines to do whatever they want to do to the army of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh will also hand over the army of Israel into the hand of the Philistines
